properties.name: Auschwitz
properties.description: Open: June 14, 1940First Mentioned: December 1939Evacuation: Mid January 15-19th 1945Liberation: January 27, 1945 Prisoners Include: Political Poles, Jews, handicapped, Protestant and Catholic clergy, Homosexuals, Jehovah's Witnesses, other Politicals, Gypsies, Soviet POWs Sex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish Political, Political (Communists, SPD, any other political opposition to the Nazi's), Gypsies, Resistance, Jehovah's Witness, Jewish, Homosexuals, Career Criminals, asocials, POWs Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: IG Farben, Herman Goring Works, German Equipment Works, German Earth and Stone Company, Gollenschow Portland Cement Plant, German Food Concern Ltd. Population Total: Around 1.3 Million Total Died: Nearly 1.1 Million Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Bergen-Belsen
properties.description: Open: 1940-1943 POW camp, March 1943 Concentration CampLiberation: April 15, 1945 Prisoners Include: Political Poles, Jews, handicapped, Protestant and Catholic clergy, Homosexuals, Jehovah's Witnesses, other Political’s, Gypsies, Soviet POW Sex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish, Polish, Nationals, POWs, Hungarian Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: IG Farben, Herman Goring Works, German Equipment Works, German Earth and Stone Company, Gollenschow Portland Cement Plant, German Food Concern Ltd. Population Total Died: Around 50,000 Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Buchenwald
properties.description: Open: July 15, 1937Occupied: April 14, 1945Liberation: April 11, 1945Prisoners Include: Prisoners from all over Europe, 35 different nationalities representedSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jews, Political, Asocial, Jehovah's Witnesses, Gypsies, Homosexuals Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Prisoners worked at over 90 locations and firms including Hugo-Schneider, BMW, Friedrich Krupp Inc, Volkswagenwerke Dernau, BrabagPopulation Total: 250,000 Total Died: approximately 56,000. Of these deaths, 34,375 are registered in the camp records Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Dachau
properties.description: Open: March 22, 1933First Mentioned: March 20, 1933Evacuation: April 26, 1945Liberation: April 29, 1945 Prisoners Include: Prisoners from 37 different countriesSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish Political, Political (Communists, SPD, any other political opposition to the Nazi's), Gypsies, Resistance, Jehovah's Witness, Jewish, Homosexuals, Career Criminals, asocials, POWs Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Deutsche Ausrustungswerke, BMW, Messerschmidt, DornierPopulation Total: Over 200,000 Total Died: International Tracing Service-32,009, Article figures over 40,000 Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Flossenbürg
properties.description: Open: Spring 1938Evacuation: April 15-20, 1945Liberation: April 23, 1945 Prisoners Include: Prisoners from all over EuropeSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: All Nazi opposition: Religious (Jews in large numbers didn’t arrive till fall 1944), Political, ethnic, POWs Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: German Earth and Stone Works, Ltd., Arado Flugzeugwerke, BMW, Zeiss-Ikon AG, J.C. Muller & Co. Heinkel-Werke, Astrawerke AGPopulation Total: 100,000 Total Died: 30,000 MapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Gross Rosen (Groß Rosen)
properties.description: Open: May 11, 1940Liberation: February 13, 1945 Prisoners Include: Prisoners from all over Europe, mostly Polish, Russian, others include French, Hungarian, Dutch, Austrian, and OthersSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: All Nazi Opposition: Religion, Ethnic, Political, POW, No more Jews after October 1942 Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Siemens, IG Farben, Barthold, Focke-Wulf, Friedrich Krupp, Deutsche Industriewerke AGPopulation Total: Approximately 120,000 Total Died: at least 7,500 died due to camp conditions, possibly double that number Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Herzogenbusch
properties.description: Open: January 5, 1943Evacuation: September 4/5, 1944Prisoners Include: Mostly Belgian and French, other countries as wellSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: All Nazi Opposition: Ethnic, Religion, Political, Career Criminals Associated Firms Include: Luftwaffe, Organization Todt, Bosch, Continental-Werk Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Luftwaffe, Organization Todt, Bosch, Continental- WerkPopulation Total: 42,000 Lists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Kovno
properties.description: Open: Fall 1943Evacuation: July 8-12, 1944Liberation: August 1, 1944 Prisoners Include: LithuanianSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish Population Total Died: 50,000 Lists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Krakau-Plaszow
properties.description: First Mentioned: June/July 1942Evacuation: Start in June of 1944, end January 1945Liberation: January 14, 1945 Prisoners Include: Jews and Non-Jews, GypsiesSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jews and Non-Jews, Gypsies Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Kabelwerk, Heinkel, Deutsche AusrustungswerkePopulation Total: Between 30,000-50,000 people went through the camp, some only for days Total Died: Between 5,000-8,000 prisoners were killed there, not including those who were transported to the camp area to be shot immediately Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Lublin-Majdanek
properties.description: Open: October 1941 as "Prisoner of War Camp of the Waffen SS in Lublin"; officially designated as a concentration camp on February 16, 1943.First Mentioned: July 20-21, 1941Evacuation: April 1944 and July 22, 1944Liberation: July 23, 1944 Prisoners Include: Slovaks, Polish, German, Russian, Belarusian, Galician, Austrian, 29 different nationalities represented.Sex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Polish, Jewish, Soviet POWs, Polish Political Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Deutsche Ausrustungswerke, Schultz and Co.Population Total: 240,000-250,000, but does not included those sent there to be killed Total Died: 1948 Polish scholar estimated that 360,000 prisoners died or were killed at Majdanek. In 1981, a German court gave 200,000 as the minimum number of Majdanek’s victims, while a recent Polish study posits the number may be as “low” as 170,000 Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Mauthausen
properties.description: Open: Fall 1938Liberation: May 5, 1945 Prisoners Include: Polish, Russian, Spanish, Czech, Hungarian, Dutch as well as many other countries in EuropeSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Political, Red Spaniards, Soviet POWs, Polish/Czech/Hungarian Jews Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Steyr-Daimler Puch AG, Gear Wheel Factory, Dyckerhoff and Widmann, Auto-Hanzel, Deutsche Erd-und Steinwerke GmbHPopulation Total: about 200,000 Total Died: 100,000+ Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Mittelbau
properties.description: Open: October 28, 1944 officially becomes camp separate of Buchenwald; originally it was the Buchenwald sub-camp Dora that opened August 28, 1943Evacuation: April 4/5, 1945Liberation: April 11, 1945 Prisoners Include: Russian, Polish, French, German, Belgian, Italian, Czech, Hungarian, and other German occupied countriesSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Political, Communists, Military internees, Gypsies, Jews, as well as all other opposition to the Nazi way of life Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Deutsche Ausrustungswerke, BMW, Messerschmidt, DornierPopulation Total: 60,000 Total Died: 20,000 Survivor TestimoniesHistorical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Natzweiler-Struthof
properties.description: Open: May 1, 1941Evacuation: August 31-September 4, 1944Liberation: November 23, 1944 Prisoners Include: French, German, Norwegian, Dutch, Luxembourgers, Eastern European, Sinti, Roma Sex: Men, no women in the actual Natzweiler Camp, but a few Women in subcamps Prisoner Type: Communists, Gypsies, Jewish prisoners sent directly to Natzweiler subcamps, Political, Alsatians or Mosellans who had resisted forced enlistment in the German army Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Daimler-Benz, Wuste-Werk, Krupp, Wayss & Freytag, Heinkel, Messerschmitt, Dunlop FactoryPopulation Total: Over 46,000 Total Died: 25-30% of all interned Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Neuengamme
properties.description: Open: Originally opened as a sub-camp of Sachsenhausen in 1938. Becomes an independent Concentration Camp in the spring of 1940Evacuation: April 19, 1945Prisoners Include: Polish, Russian, French, Danish, Norwegian, Serbian, Estonian, Ukrainian, Greek, Czech, Belgian, Italian, Latvian, LithuanianSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Soviet POWs, Jews from the east, Political, Religious, Asocial, Career Criminals Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Deutsche Ausrustungswerke, BMW, Messerschmidt, DornierPopulation Total: 104,000 Total Died: around 44,000 to 55,000 Historical Film FootageMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Ravensbrück
properties.description: Open: May 15, 1939 opens as a Women’s camp; April 1941 begins holding male prisoners as wellEvacuation: Late April 1945, April 20-28thLiberation: May 1, 1945 Prisoners Include: Polish, Soviet, German, Austrian, Hungarian, French, Czech, Belgium, Dutch, Luxembourgian, and YugoslavianSex: Mostly Women, Men later Prisoner Type: Asocial, Political, Jewish, Homosexuals, Soviet POWs, Roma, Sinti, Jehovah’s Witnesses Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: SS-Company for the Utilization of Textiles and Leather Ltd., Deutshe Versuchsanstalt fur Ernahrung und Verpflegung GmbH, Siemens & HalskePopulation Total: 123,000 Women, 20,000 Men Total Died: 25,000-26,000 Women Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Riga-Kaiserwald
properties.description: Open: Late Summer 1943Evacuation: August 6-October 10, 1944Prisoners Include: German, Austrian, Czech, Latvian, Lithuanian, as well as other occupied Eastern European CountriesSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish, Mostly Jews from ghettos Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Opel, AEG, WehrmachtPopulation Total: 15,000 Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Sachsenhausen
properties.description: Open: July 1936Liberation: April 22, 1945 Prisoners Include: Prisoners were from various European countries including Russia, Poland, France, Netherlands, Norway, German, and AustrianSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Soviet POWs, Homosexuals, Asocial, Gypsies, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Jewish, Political, Criminals, Polish Population Total: More than 200,000 Total Died: somewhere between 40,000 and 50,000 Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Stutthof
properties.description: Open: September 2, 1939Evacuation: January 25, 1945Prisoners Include: Polish, French, Russian, German, Dutch, Latvian, Lithuanian, Hungarian, Czech, Estonian, Yugoslavian and other European countriesSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish, Polish, Political, Russian, Asocials, Criminals, Homosexuals, Gypsies, Priests, Jehovah's Witnesses and all other Nazi opposition Associated Firms include: Luftwaffe, Dehlert Company, Stolp Rolling Stock Repair Works, TWL-Thorn, Kieferling, and Metzger u. Co. Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Deutsche Ausrustungswerke, BMW, Messerschmidt, DornierPopulation Total: 110,000 registered prisoners Total Died: between 65,000 and 80,000 Survivor TestimoniesMapsLists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer

properties.name: Vaivara
properties.description: Open: September 19, 1943Evacuation: Begins March 1944 lasts until August/September 1944Prisoners Include: Baltic Jews from Vilnius and Kaunas ghettos, and some Czech and GermanSex: Men, Women Prisoner Type: Jewish, Roma, POWs Firms that exploited the labor of prisoners from this camp include: Kontinentale Ol AG, BaltölPopulation Total: approximately 9,000 Total Died: 1,506 Lists of Names Related to the CampHolocaust Encyclopedia Layer
